review_title: I feel valued, meaningful work with students/clients, opportunities abound
pros: I truly feel valued here at RVU. People express their appreciation often, and my value is reflected in my compensation and in the budget granted for professional development. The therapeutic intervention I do here is brief, but meaningful and varied. My interaction with students and the campus community on outreach efforts is positive and people are open to new ideas and innovation. There are many opportunities for interaction and collaboration with faculty and other staff members.
cons: It might take some adjustment to the pace if you are used to larger institutions that move and grow more slowly.

pros: I enjoyed working with the students and knowing I was contributing to improving healthcare overall. And years ago, this was a great place to work.
cons: RVU has gone downhill quickly. They're trying to grow faster than they are able. With each new campus, they aren't keeping up with staff and they aren't taking care of existing issues. The company that bought RVU is running it into the ground, trying to make it more like St. George University. They fired the last president and replaced him with someone far less passionate about education and caring of RVU's employees. The person in charge of many of the administrative departments is terrible but no one will do anything about her--despite the high turnover underneath her. They claim to care about things like integrity and diversity but it's just for show. And as someone mentioned before, retaliation and the HR Dept is a huge problem there.

review_title: Poor compensation, upper management out of touch
pros: My core team was an incredible group of people: dedicated, productive, and amazing at their jobs. But we were not compensated fairly for our work or recognized for it.
cons: Opportunities for advancement were rarely talked about and ultimately never materialized. Professional development was not a priority for the department head. Compensation at this University is NOT competitive for the area, and more than one employee spoke about experiencing discrimination in this regard. There is a lack of communication from the leadership teams and HR. The University is growing rapidly but failing to fully staff administrative departments. I would not recommend working at this place at this time.

pros: relaxed, fun, easy place to work

job_title: Human Resources Talent Coordinator in Ivins, UT
pros: Inclusive, Appreciated, high core values, work-life balance important to them, and Goal-Oriented and is interested in my personal growth as an employee.
cons: I've worked for 9 months and right now I don't have a con.

pros: The medical students and faculty were outstanding. Great place to work the first few months...completely the opposite.
cons: The ownership and upper management had many problems.  A great deal of in-fighting between the CFO/COO and anyone who dared to question him or disagree.  A school that has had 6 Presidents since it opened in 2008!

pros: Offered great training as well as ability to function independently. Was a great opportunity to contribute to many successes in both the students and community.
